But what about ketosis and the growth hormone released in this state to protect our muscles? Some case studies show a human could survive without food for several weeks and not lose any muscle mass, or at least extremely little. People would also stop being hungry within the first week and and would continue to feel fine (No loss of strength or being tired all the time) until they'd get hungry again at which point they do start loosing muscle mass.
The best example I can currently remember is the case of Angus Barbieri, but I have read and heard about more cases and even tried it myself for a week. I too did not feel hungry anymore from the 4th day and on, I also didn't feel tired or cold all the time. I measured my blood-sugar level regularly which stayed very stable just around 4 mmol/l while having no symptoms associated with low blood-sugar. In the end I ended my research simply because I missed the taste due to a mental addiction to sugar(or food in general). I might try it again in the future though.
If you want to know more about my own experiment you can reply or send me a personal message.

I personally LOVE this channel, but here I think there is one big misconception, the protein breaking at the begining is only for the proteins that are not being used, after 48-72h of starvation the body also segregates growth hormone which keeps the muscles pretty much intacts. Actually other processes are taking place in the body after all the glucose in the liver is depleted, like breaking the fat storage to produce ketogenic bodies which serves as a fuel for the full body, included the brain. Also some sugars are also made in the liver for special needs in the brain.
After the fat stores are depleted yes, bad processes starts to appear, but before is safe as long as you take essential vitamins and minerals, this is also called fasting and has been "proven" really good for the body and specially the brain.

Longest fast on record was a Scottish man in the early 70's identified by documentation simply as "A.B." but later identified as a man named Angus Barbieri. At 27 years old he successfully completed a medically supervised therapeutic fast, starting at a morbidly obese 456lbs, and completing the fast at 180lbs. He was able to successfully maintain a healthy weight(<200lbs), even several years after the initial loss. His fast lasted 384 days. Perhaps the most interesting fact about Angus's case is that he did not have any loose skin after his dramatic loss of weight, presumably due to the process of autophagy whereby during a fast, the body breaks down defective and unused proteins to be recycled. There have even been reports of people losing scars during a fast due to this process.

The body is extremely ineffective at converting extra glucose into body fat. This process is called denovo lipogenesis and wouldn't amount to much fat gain even if you binge ate a bunch of fruits and veggies (pure carbs).
